results.title: Elektra: a tragedy in one act
results.brief_description: Clytemnestra, Queen of Thebes, has murdered her husband with the help of her lover Aegisthus. Electra, her daughter, has taken her younger brother Orestes to safety in a foreign country where he is being raised to avenge his father. Whilst the palace residents (including Chrysothemis, Electra’s sister) have come to terms with the new situation, Electra keeps the memory of her father’s murder alive, waiting for the day of retribution. Hugo von Hofmannsthal’s opera is based on Sophocles’s Electra, with music by Richard Strauss magnificently performed by Leonie Rysanek (Elektra), Astrid Varnay (Clytemnestra), Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau (Orestes) and members of the Konzertvereinigung Wiener Staatsopernchor. Karl Bohm conducts the Wiener Philharmoniker. Sung in German. A booklet containing a synopsis is included.

results.title: Elegant girl or the drive for reliability
results.brief_description: A musical advertisement for the Vauxhall motor car. Makes a technical comparison between vintage and later model cars and shows the detailed testing the modern Vauxhall goes through to ensure its all-round quality and performance is at a maxiumum.

results.title: Electrostatic charges and forces
results.brief_description: This film shows how positive and negative charges are created: defines such basic concepts as insulator, conductor and electric field; and introduces Coulomb’s law, used to measure electrostatic charges. A laboratory demonstration of Faraday’s ice-pail experiment is presented. The film also shows how the principles of electrostatic charges and forces can be used to explain the operation of the Van de Graaff generator.

results.title: Electrons in harness
results.creator_credit: Verity Films, Seafield Head and David Cons
results.brief_description: The film is set in a modern electronics research laboratory where work is seen being carried out on, for example, electron beam machining, high vacuum techniques, cathode ray tubes and microcircuits. The relation between research and production is illustrated, and the end sequence illustrates the many fields in which electronics play a vital part including medicine, telecommunication and defence.

results.title: Electrons and electronics: an introduction
results.brief_description: Explains how such electronic devices as vacuum tubes and transistors work and how they are put to use in the fields of communication, transportation, medicine and industry. A visit to a broadcasting station shows us what part electronics plays in radio and television.

results.title: Electrons
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Harry B. Lemon
results.brief_description: Part of the Physical Sciences series. By means of various photographic techniques including animation, the hypothesis that electricity consists of unit elementary charges is supported by observation of phenomena associated with the conduction of electricity in liquids, gases, and vacuums. The conclusion drawn is that the fundamental unit of an electrical charge is the electron.

results.title: Electronics: an introduction
results.creator_credit: BFA Educational Media and Victor and Ellen Landweber
results.brief_description: Follows the development of electronic devices: a conductor, an electric light bulb, a diode vacuum tube, an amplifier, and the transistor. Concludes with a brief survey of electronic applications. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Electronics in action
results.creator_credit: Raytheon Manufacturing Company and Lee A. Ellis
results.brief_description: The history of Raytheon Manufacturing Company since its founding in 1922. The company’s facilities and products; the electronics industry - guided missiles, electronic computers, medical diathermy equipment, vacuum tubes and small transistors.

results.title: Electronics at work
results.brief_description: Explains the six basic functions of electronic tubes and shows how each type of tube is used in a variety of industrial and military applications. The film also shows the importance of electronics in the aluminium and magnesium industries providing the vast quantities of direct current required for speedy, economical production.
